channel.title: BBC News - UK Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Fewest people on furlough since pandemic began
item.description: Under-25s are coming off furlough twice as fast as all other age brackets, says the Treasury.

item.title: RNLI donations increase after migrant rescue criticism
item.description: The lifeboat charity says it has been "overwhelmed" by support after it released footage of Channel rescues.

item.title: Covid: University students could be told jabs are required - Raab
item.description: There will be "advance warning" if vaccines become compulsory for halls, the foreign secretary says.

item.title: Holocaust memorial outside Parliament to go ahead
item.description: Fears have been raised that the site could become a terrorist target, but ministers say it will be safe.

item.title: UK already undergoing disruptive climate change
item.description: Last year was the third warmest, fifth wettest and eighth sunniest on record in the UK, scientists warn.

item.title: Price tag for new flagship royal yacht could hit £250m
item.description: The defence secretary confirms the cost of the new "floating embassy" could be £100m higher than expected.

item.title: Official Secrets Act: Do government plans threaten investigative journalism?
item.description: Campaigners and reporters say planned changes to the Official Secrets Act threaten press freedoms.

item.title: Malala says girls' education 'worth fighting for'
item.description: The campaigner tells a summit that improving education should be a key part of the pandemic recovery.

item.title: Boris Johnson predicts steady economic recovery post-pandemic
item.description: Boris Johnson still warns of "bumps on the road" ahead as the IMF predicts 7% growth for the UK economy.

item.title: Covid: Self-isolation rule changes on 16 August 'nailed on' - PM
item.description: Recent falls in cases are encouraging but it is too early to draw conclusions, Boris Johnson says.

item.title: Covid: UK sends nine million vaccines to vulnerable countries
item.description: The government has promised to donate 100m surplus doses to other countries before the middle of 2022.

item.title: Covid: No quarantine for fully jabbed US and EU travellers
item.description: Ministers hope the rule change in England, Scotland and Wales will help reunite family and friends.

item.title: Home secretary meets Birmingham pub bombings families
item.description: Victims' families say they are "closer than we ever have been" as they call for a public inquiry.

item.title: Critics give mixed response to ministers' £1.6bn disability strategy
item.description: The government says it is a once in a generation transformative plan but critics say it is lacking.

item.title: Honda workers in Swindon to face 'reality check' after it closes
item.description: Swindon car plant prepares to stop production on July 30 after 35 years of production.

item.title: Lib Dem MSP Alex Cole-Hamilton announces leadership bid
item.description: Alex Cole-Hamilton is currently the only person to have put their name forward to succeed Willie Rennie.

item.title: Let more Afghan interpreters resettle in UK, say ex-military chiefs
item.description: More Afghans who worked for British forces should be allowed to resettle in the UK, former military chiefs say.

item.title: Matt Hancock: Newmarket Town Council passes no-confidence vote
item.description: A council in the former health secretary's constituency accuses the MP of "hypocrisy and hubris".

item.title: Electric car charging prices 'must be fair' say MPs
item.description: Consumers should not have to pay excessive prices to use public car charging, MPs say.

item.title: Covid: Turning down Covid vaccine is selfish, says Michael Gove
item.description: The Cabinet Office minister said those declining a jab could see themselves barred from events.

item.title: Boris Johnson pledges to to target crime and anti-social behaviour
item.description: More local officers and wider use of public 'chain gangs' are promised, but police demand extra funding.

item.title: IMF upgrades UK economic forecast
item.description: Wealth gap between countries could widen due to differing access to Covid vaccines, the IMF says.

item.title: My dog Dilyn can't control his romantic urges, says Boris Johnson
item.description: Boris Johnson reveals Downing Street's resident Jack Russell-cross has a weakness for human legs.

item.title: Contaminated-blood inquiry: Former Health Minister Clarke denies responsibility
item.description: Lord Clarke is the first senior health minister from the 1980s to testify on the NHS scandal.

item.title: Brexit: EU pauses legal action against UK over NI Protocol 'breaches'
item.description: The action began in March after the UK made a move to change the implementation of the protocol.

item.title: Labour's Wes Streeting back at work and cancer free
item.description: Wes Streeting says he counts his "lucky stars" after surgery to remove a kidney.

item.title: Covid: More pinged workers eligible for daily tests instead of isolation
item.description: Waste workers, prison staff and defence workers will be able to avoid isolation, the government says.

item.title: GMB withdraw London Labour funding over sacking
item.description: The union says it will no longer fund London Labour due to the "callous" dismissal of Gary Bolister.

item.title: Brexit: EU publishes proposals to simplify NI Protocol
item.description: The UK government says plans on the transport of medicines, food and animals do not go far enough.

item.title: Give workers full rights from day one – Labour
item.description: Deputy leader Angela Rayner sets out plans for a "new deal" for workers post-pandemic.

item.title: COP26 climate summit president says progress made, but not enough
item.description: The first in-person climate meeting in 18 months sees some tentative progress, but no breakthroughs.

item.title: Almost 600 migrant Channel crossings at weekend
item.description: Home secretary says she is determined to stop journeys, after record number of attempts last month.

item.title: National Adoption Strategy: £48m to improve services in England
item.description: A new National Adoption Strategy aims to enhance support to families and end a postcode lottery.

item.title: Sajid Javid calls on younger people to have Covid vaccines
item.description: Fighting Covid has been a "race" with the baton now being passed from older to young people, says the health secretary

item.title: Shapps on opening up England to visitors from US and Europe
item.description: The government has tried to "err on the side of caution and safety" on opening up borders to visitors from abroad, says the transport secretary.

item.title: Michael Gove on vaccine passports at events with big crowds
item.description: People should be “confident” those attending large-scale events are “less likely to be carriers of the virus”, the Cabinet Office Minister says.

item.title: Boris Johnson on Covid infection rates falling for six days
item.description: The prime minister urges people not to “run away with premature conclusions” amid a fall in positive test numbers.

item.title: Angela Rayner on Labour's plan for flexible working
item.description: Many workers have been "incredibly flexible" working through the Covid pandemic says Labour's deputy leader.

item.title: Zimbabwean with football dreams to be kicked out of UK
item.description: Christopher Arundell grew up in the UK but after doing time in jail is being deported to Zimbabwe.

item.title: What happens to British ships when satellites don't work?
item.description: The Royal Navy and merchant fleet have no back-up if navigation systems are disrupted, experts warn.

item.title: Boris Johnson's police numbers claim fact-checked
item.description: A look at the prime minister's claims about crime statistics, police numbers and funding.

item.title: John Stonehouse: Bizarre tale of the MP who faked his own death
item.description: Was John Stonehouse a spy who betrayed his country? Or a naive and broken man? James Naughtie investigates.

item.title: Brexit: What's the Northern Ireland Protocol?
item.description: Urgent changes to the post-Brexit Northern Ireland Protocol have been called for by the UK government.

item.title: Cummings: Eight takeaways from his interview
item.description: The PM's former chief adviser on lockdowns, Downing Street rows, Brexit and coup discussions.

item.title: Covid rules: What has changed?
item.description: Major changes to lockdown rules have taken effect in England and Scotland, but some restrictions remain.

item.title: How does Dominic Cummings now earn a living?
item.description: A profile of Boris Johnson's former right-hand-man, who has turned into his chief tormentor.

item.title: Coventry City of Culture: The women who helped shape a 'city of justice'
item.description: Coventry women have always been at the heart of the struggle for social justice, a historian says.

item.title: Foreign aid: Who will be hit by the UK government cuts?
item.description: The UK government is reducing its spending this year on foreign aid - with major consequences for some recipients.

item.title: What more can be done to stop racist abuse online?
item.description: Abuse directed at England footballers has prompted calls for more action to tackle hate online.

item.title: Are lots of people deleting the NHS Covid app?
item.description: Are people using the government's Covid app or are they deleting it?

item.title: Covid: Will free school meals continue over summer holidays?
item.description: A year on from Marcus Rashford's successful campaign, what is the current situation?

item.title: Does political pressure shape pandemic decisions?
item.description: With Scotland and England on the road out of lockdown, does political pressure encourage a "four nation" approach?

item.title: Ministers see off MPs' attempts to amend new crime bill
item.description: MPs have approved controversial new public order laws but ministers signal concessions to come.
